content:
31
												Hello Fellow Wastelanders,I strongly recommend Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition! First of all, it's Fallout 3 with the addition of all of the downloadable content! It's definitely worth the money and is cheaper than buying Fallout 3 and then buying all of the D.L.C. First of all, Fallout 3 was the first game in the series to introduce the first person shooter type style, and from this point on, it has been the only style that they have stuck to. The game takes place in the capital of the United States after a horrific war in which you are a survivor in a great underground vault. The game's storyline is compelling but after a while, you seem to forget what it was as you run off and do all of the magnificent side quests. The game's health and karma make it different from some of the other roleplaying games that you may have played before. Ultimately, the game can last you hours on end and it's loads of fun! I strongly recommend this game over the traditional Fallout 3 due to the fact that it is the same thing but with all of the downloadable content. This game was also clever in taking the turn based system in Fallout 1 and Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game by creating V.A.T.S. This system allows you to target enemies in specific areas of their body while freezing time. The V.A.T.S. system would then be seen throughout the rest of the Fallout series so far and received a slight change in Fallout 4 as the enemies are then allowed to move in V.A.T.S., but slowly. Overall, the creativity is astonishing, the stories are incredible, the side quests allow for hours of play, what is there not to love? If you liked this story, you'll love Fallout: New Vegas, though, as this story is slightly less entertaining than that of Fallout: New Vegas. It's a load of fun, though, definitely worth every penny!-Kyle JamesP.S. The game doesn't function on Windows Eight or above, here is a video to help you fix the problem and enjoy the game!

content:
r 25, 2015
												The best things that I have to say about Fallout 3 all have to do with how they handled the atmosphere, backstory and location. Setting FO3 in DC was a great choice, what better place to set a Fallout story? They really captured the Fallout feeling with this game but it's clear they put a different spin on it. It has more of a hopeful feeling instead of the darker, horror like sound that Mark Morgan brought to the first 2, which I liked a lot but I think I like Inon Zur's work better. Fallout 3 does a great job at fleshing out the world too, some of the best stories you'll see in this game are found in the computer terminal logs and random notes you'll find, they did a great job with those and clearly put a lot of work into them.         The main quest is overall hit or miss but will possibly leave you feeling frustrated if you don't have broken steel dlc. I didn't like it, I think the concept is good even though it's pretty clear they took it from Fallout Tactics, it could've been executed a lot better and it definiately felt forced. The DLC is one of my favorite things about this one, Point Lookout is one of my favorite locations in the series so far, the Pitt and Anchorage are also great. My biggest complaint about this game is how they copy pasted a few of the critical story moments from the first 2 games and shamelessly took credit for it from people who never played the first 2. A good example of this would be how you get exiled from vault 101 or how they had a settlement based around and inside a tanker.        Overall, it's a good game, I know it's controversial among some sections of the Fallout community and I was kind of on the Fallout 3 hate bandwagon for a while but I think there is a lot of things this game does right that makes it unique from the other entries. I think Bethesda can make a great Fallout game, they just need to put more emphasis on the main quest and lore next time.

y 6, 2016
												A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.GL HF ;D

r 10, 2015
												If you have Windows 10 you will have to go to the microsoft market place and down load thier 36Mb PC client  http://www.xbox.com/en-US/Live/PC/DownloadClient. Then go to your steam and find your Fallout3 game from your Steam library. Right mouse click the games name in your Library then go to Properties. Then go to Local files. Then click Browse Local files. Go down to the Icon that says Fallout3 with the guys face. Not the Fallout. EXE and not the FalloutLauncher. Right Click on the Fallout3 icon go to Properties go to Compatibility then click Run as Administrator. Your good to go under Windows 10. You do NOT have to pick a Compatibility mode. Jut make sure Run as Administrator is checked you dont need to pick a different OS type to play the game. If you dont have the Microsoft market place PC client installed it wont work at all. Easies fix to get Fallout3 to work under Windows 10 & Pro.

er 23, 2015
												I recommend this game to anyone that is a true Fallout fan.Pros:Great story, however, it's the same 'Go find ____' story from Fallout 1 and 2.Highly replayable, mods can extend the game's life.Includes a great collection of weapons such as the iconic 10mm pistol.Many enemies return in their three dimensional forms.The atmosphere is dark when indoors and calm when outside.The combat is no longer, "You miss," 90 percent of the time, and it is not turn-based.The downloadable content adds more fun to an already complete game.The wasteland is a new area not previously seen.Cons:The game needs a patch for certain computers to run.Everything is green, and I mean EVERYTHING. *The character customization could have been better, all the characters look the same. *There are so many bugs in this game, exterminators have nightmares about it. *There are not a lot of encounters in the game.*: Mods can fix these issues.The game is magnificent. Of course it could have been more than it became, and surely Fallout 3 did become more than it was when released in 2009 due to the large community of modders who saved this game from oblivion. Fallout 3 is a video game that began Fallout's debut into the modern era of video games, and it is a true Fallout game not made by Interplay.Final Score: 9.25/10

												Masterpiece of modern RPG's.Fallout 3 is an incredible game, although with its flaws. Slightly buggy and prone to crashing, this game is not as stable as you would hope.However, the general gameplay is amazing, With masses of replayability, Fallout 3 offers something different everytime you start a new game. Want to take an all-good play style and only shoot when you deem 100% neccesary for your own safety? You can do that. Want to kill every last thing on site with no piy or remorse? You can do that. Want to breeze through the story with no care for any of the side quests? You can do almot anything in this game, and I highly reccommend this game because of that.The graphics are pretty darn good. For an older open world RPG with such a large world size, it has aged quite well graphically, and will still look good for years to come.I have been playing this game for close to 5 hours on PC, but I have completed Fallout 3 multiple times on Xbox 360. Making the jump onto PC gaming and playing Fallout 3 could not feel better. This game is buggy, but amazing on PC and (obviously) is the platform I would reccomend you get it on (although there is about 30 minutes of bug fixing you have to do yourself, but it is 100% worth it).Overall, I'd give this game a solid 9/10. Buggy and prone to crashes, but is an absolute masterpiece of modern RPG's.

content:
er 11, 2015
												Okay, well Fallout 4 came out yesterday and I pre-ordered it on xbox one, bad me, I know. But good me because I hear the PC port sucks, really bad. So I figure some folks bought Fallout 4 and want to try Fallout 3, because they want to get the bad taste out of their mouths or love it and want to play the game that started the fps version of it all. Well this review is for beginners of the Fallout franchise because I'm what you'd call a verteran, I've played all the games except those brotherhood of steel spin offs that suck, but they aren't considered games. By the way ths is spoiler free so enjoy. I wake up in a vault on my 2nd playthrough on PC, since I was good last time I want to be evil. Now the vault is a whole can of worms that are actually the evil that are known as spoilers so I'll just tell you some things I did for fun in the vault. I took off all my clothes and danced on a table at my birthday party after insulting a bully's mother. I got a BB gun and shot my dad until he fell unconcious and then took a picture with him, still unconcious. I shot a bunch of security guards, killed the overseer, and laughed in a girl's face after killing her dad. I then arose from the vault as a twelve year old boy would arise in the morning freaking out on the release day of Fallout 4. I went to a nearby settlement and improved my vault suit, making it 101 armor? I made a promise to some lousy sherrif to disarm a nuke in town square. I went into the town bar and promised a guy I would help him activate the nuke and blow up the town after having some fun with it and getting an evil companion in it. I went upstairs in the bar/hotel and killed all of the people sleeping in their beds with my baseball bat. (A lot of them are essential NPC's, yes you can kill almost anyone in Fallout 3 with the exception of your dad and a few others out of an entire world of characters.) I blew up the town after getting some info where to find my dad on the bar owner's computer, who I also killed whilst he was sleeping. I helped a radio broadcaster with his radio dish then proceeded to kill him to gain my evil karma back like I do with all good quests which I only do for the experience, I can't talk about anything else now because it's not spoiler friendly so I'll talk about a couple of side quests you can do in the game. Become a member of a tree cult and talk to a giant tree, that's actually a mutant from the second game (Fallout 2) named Harry. After the game if you have broken steel you decisions actually matter as you see what happened when normal players had to end the game. You can help some slaves liberate the lincoln memorial of slavers so they can live in the lincoln memorial. You can help a human hating ghoul assassinate humans. You can help a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ get to Rivet city. You can destroy a giant military base full of american patriot soldiers. You can get a mini nuke launcher and blow up a giant behemoth. (That last one wasn't a quest itself, but it was part of one, and it was really cool.) This game is so immersive, and unlike Fallout 4 (which I love.) You're not playing as the character who lost his son, no, you're playing as you. 10/10 buy this game now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
28, 2015
												In truth, I've dedicated somewhere in the range of at least 400-500 hours to Fallout 3 across my life, including the PS3 version. Running the game through Fallout Script Extender prohibits time from being logged, but I've dedicated a lot of time to the Capital Wasteland, and yet I've only completed the story once, never explored evil karma, and have only finished two of the DLCs. There is just such a grand level of exploration in this game that it's hard not to daydream about your second, post-apocalyptic life whenever you're away from it.Though I found myself hard-pressed to engage in the original isometric Interplay titles, Bethesda's 3D take on the setting brings it all to an atmosphere that's borderline life-like, and was the foundation for Obsidian's New Vegas, my all-time favourite video game. Truly, Fallout 3 was a major part of my childhood, and remains a heartily recommendable action-RPG to this day, though I fear a vast majority of its content will become invalidated with the impending release of Fallout 4 (unlike New Vegas, Fallout 3 does not have the combat, dialogue, and variety to survive a direct successor).Questlines are sparse and relatively linear, with only a couple of different outcomes for most, and many towns simply don't make sense (a village actually built around a bomb, a civilization made exclusively of children, an underpopulated and undergunned slum surrounded by raiders and mutants). There is limited weapon and enemy variety, and navigating sewers and metro tunnels can become enragingly confusing. However, on the flip side, the action is a gory delight, and all of the environments are lovably crafted down to the smallest of details, even if the world abides by its own bizarre sense of logic.An easy argument in favour of this game is the modding community- an outlet for solving essentially every negative I have listed. However, it is also a display of Bethesda's oftentimes lackluster game design, and does not help anyone seeking a purely vanilla adventure. Overall, anyone looking for a game that's rich in content variety, solid RPG mechanics and a believable world should likely be pointed toward New Vegas (which I more strongly recommend regardless), but otherwise, this is a nice time sink until Fallout 4.

												The best things that I have to say about Fallout 3 all have to do with how they handled the atmosphere, backstory and location. Setting FO3 in DC was a great choice, what better place to set a Fallout story? They really captured the Fallout feeling with this game but it's clear they put a different spin on it. It has more of a hopeful feeling instead of the darker, horror like sound that Mark Morgan brought to the first 2, which I liked a lot but I think I like Inon Zur's work better. Fallout 3 does a great job at fleshing out the world too, some of the best stories you'll see in this game are found in the computer terminal logs and random notes you'll find, they did a great job with those and clearly put a lot of work into them.         The main quest is overall hit or miss but will possibly leave you feeling frustrated if you don't have broken steel dlc. I didn't like it, I think the concept is good even though it's pretty clear they took it from Fallout Tactics, it could've been executed a lot better and it definiately felt forced. The DLC is one of my favorite things about this one, Point Lookout is one of my favorite locations in the series so far, the Pitt and Anchorage are also great. My biggest complaint about this game is how they copy pasted a few of the critical story moments from the first 2 games and shamelessly took credit for it from people who never played the first 2. A good example of this would be how you get exiled from vault 101 or how they had a settlement based around and inside a tanker.        Overall, it's a good game, I know it's controversial among some sections of the Fallout community and I was kind of on the Fallout 3 hate bandwagon for a while but I think there is a lot of things this game does right that makes it unique from the other entries. I think Bethesda can make a great Fallout game, they just need to put more emphasis on the main quest and lore next time.

												Fallout Three is a very progressed game for it's time. Playing it wasn't boring, but it wasn't fun after the second play through either. The game all though it follows the lore and feel of the, 'Fallout' series doesn't seem to have that level of freedom the first games did. All though it is a sandbox game and has it's freedom to a limit, there is nothing to say it isn't fun. So for all those people not going to buy Fallout four off the bat, this is a good game to go back to if you're starting a new.

er 29, 2015
												Fallout 3....       The question is not whether you should buy the game, the question is why you're still reading this review                                         and not buying the game right now.        Welcome to Washington DC, home of completely normal human beings.  Visit destroyed landmarks, flourishing cities, an underground town run by children, an aessload of metro stations, caves infested with mutated crabs, and a hotel converted into a slaver camp.  Here, you can meet all kinds on unsavory figures, from giant, angry, green men who hate militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor, to a group of militaristic people dressed in futuristic power armor who hate giant, angry, green men.  You can also wield unique weapons, such as the Firelance, a strange incindiary Alien pistol, to a modified vaccum cleaner that can fire ANYTHING. ANYTHING!!!  Oh yeah, please don't hate the ghouls. Why would you hate the ghouls? TREAT THEM AS EQUALS, DAMMIT!!!Holy craep, I can't even give this game a rating, because whatever the max is, it's just multitplied by ten.100/10 : 1,000/100 : 10,000/1,000

content:
er 29, 2014
												Masterpiece of modern RPG's.Fallout 3 is an incredible game, although with its flaws. Slightly buggy and prone to crashing, this game is not as stable as you would hope.However, the general gameplay is amazing, With masses of replayability, Fallout 3 offers something different everytime you start a new game. Want to take an all-good play style and only shoot when you deem 100% neccesary for your own safety? You can do that. Want to kill every last thing on site with no piy or remorse? You can do that. Want to breeze through the story with no care for any of the side quests? You can do almot anything in this game, and I highly reccommend this game because of that.The graphics are pretty darn good. For an older open world RPG with such a large world size, it has aged quite well graphically, and will still look good for years to come.I have been playing this game for close to 5 hours on PC, but I have completed Fallout 3 multiple times on Xbox 360. Making the jump onto PC gaming and playing Fallout 3 could not feel better. This game is buggy, but amazing on PC and (obviously) is the platform I would reccomend you get it on (although there is about 30 minutes of bug fixing you have to do yourself, but it is 100% worth it).Overall, I'd give this game a solid 9/10. Buggy and prone to crashes, but is an absolute masterpiece of modern RPG's.

content:
28, 2015
												In truth, I've dedicated somewhere in the range of at least 400-500 hours to Fallout 3 across my life, including the PS3 version. Running the game through Fallout Script Extender prohibits time from being logged, but I've dedicated a lot of time to the Capital Wasteland, and yet I've only completed the story once, never explored evil karma, and have only finished two of the DLCs. There is just such a grand level of exploration in this game that it's hard not to daydream about your second, post-apocalyptic life whenever you're away from it.Though I found myself hard-pressed to engage in the original isometric Interplay titles, Bethesda's 3D take on the setting brings it all to an atmosphere that's borderline life-like, and was the foundation for Obsidian's New Vegas, my all-time favourite video game. Truly, Fallout 3 was a major part of my childhood, and remains a heartily recommendable action-RPG to this day, though I fear a vast majority of its content will become invalidated with the impending release of Fallout 4 (unlike New Vegas, Fallout 3 does not have the combat, dialogue, and variety to survive a direct successor).Questlines are sparse and relatively linear, with only a couple of different outcomes for most, and many towns simply don't make sense (a village actually built around a bomb, a civilization made exclusively of children, an underpopulated and undergunned slum surrounded by raiders and mutants). There is limited weapon and enemy variety, and navigating sewers and metro tunnels can become enragingly confusing. However, on the flip side, the action is a gory delight, and all of the environments are lovably crafted down to the smallest of details, even if the world abides by its own bizarre sense of logic.An easy argument in favour of this game is the modding community- an outlet for solving essentially every negative I have listed. However, it is also a display of Bethesda's oftentimes lackluster game design, and does not help anyone seeking a purely vanilla adventure. Overall, anyone looking for a game that's rich in content variety, solid RPG mechanics and a believable world should likely be pointed toward New Vegas (which I more strongly recommend regardless), but otherwise, this is a nice time sink until Fallout 4.

content:
er 11, 2015
												Okay, well Fallout 4 came out yesterday and I pre-ordered it on xbox one, bad me, I know. But good me because I hear the PC port sucks, really bad. So I figure some folks bought Fallout 4 and want to try Fallout 3, because they want to get the bad taste out of their mouths or love it and want to play the game that started the fps version of it all. Well this review is for beginners of the Fallout franchise because I'm what you'd call a verteran, I've played all the games except those brotherhood of steel spin offs that suck, but they aren't considered games. By the way ths is spoiler free so enjoy. I wake up in a vault on my 2nd playthrough on PC, since I was good last time I want to be evil. Now the vault is a whole can of worms that are actually the evil that are known as spoilers so I'll just tell you some things I did for fun in the vault. I took off all my clothes and danced on a table at my birthday party after insulting a bully's mother. I got a BB gun and shot my dad until he fell unconcious and then took a picture with him, still unconcious. I shot a bunch of security guards, killed the overseer, and laughed in a girl's face after killing her dad. I then arose from the vault as a twelve year old boy would arise in the morning freaking out on the release day of Fallout 4. I went to a nearby settlement and improved my vault suit, making it 101 armor? I made a promise to some lousy sherrif to disarm a nuke in town square. I went into the town bar and promised a guy I would help him activate the nuke and blow up the town after having some fun with it and getting an evil companion in it. I went upstairs in the bar/hotel and killed all of the people sleeping in their beds with my baseball bat. (A lot of them are essential NPC's, yes you can kill almost anyone in Fallout 3 with the exception of your dad and a few others out of an entire world of characters.) I blew up the town after getting some info where to find my dad on the bar owner's computer, who I also killed whilst he was sleeping. I helped a radio broadcaster with his radio dish then proceeded to kill him to gain my evil karma back like I do with all good quests which I only do for the experience, I can't talk about anything else now because it's not spoiler friendly so I'll talk about a couple of side quests you can do in the game. Become a member of a tree cult and talk to a giant tree, that's actually a mutant from the second game (Fallout 2) named Harry. After the game if you have broken steel you decisions actually matter as you see what happened when normal players had to end the game. You can help some slaves liberate the lincoln memorial of slavers so they can live in the lincoln memorial. You can help a human hating ghoul assassinate humans. You can help a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ get to Rivet city. You can destroy a giant military base full of american patriot soldiers. You can get a mini nuke launcher and blow up a giant behemoth. (That last one wasn't a quest itself, but it was part of one, and it was really cool.) This game is so immersive, and unlike Fallout 4 (which I love.) You're not playing as the character who lost his son, no, you're playing as you. 10/10 buy this game now.

r 3, 2013
												I truely love this game. Anyone who truely knows me would know that I am a huge Bethesda fan. I have played this game for countless hours on my computer and Xbox, and would recommend it to anyone.The reason that I enjoy to play Bethesda the games the most is because they allow you to choose your path to victory, and this game does just that. You are able to put experience into any skill you want, from guns to civil abilities such as barter or science. The game designers really made you feel as if you were in Washington D.C. (the wastelands of it at least), and have given you a very interactive world that you could mess around with. In some cases, you will be given an option on whether to take the good, evil, or even neutral path to complete the quest. All of this comes together to create a perfectly created game filled with heart stopping situations, and relaxing interactions.

content:
7, 2014
												So many hours... so much time... so much love... its as they say. War? War never changes... but Fallout 3? It definitly does. Every playthrough, every character, every decision, every plot, every choice, changes the way the game is played. No two people have the exact same experience with fallout, so much so that I find myself constantly telling fallout stories with my friends as if these were real events. Everyone I know who plays fallout, has a story of their adventures, and thats what is beautiful about the game. No two experiences are the same, and it constantly offers the highest replay value and countless hours of mind blowing entertainment. Moral choices, sacrifices, survival, and even a bit of equipment management, this is a true gem that should be in every game library available. Its a game where someone can poor countless hours into exploring this world and universe that has been created, and interact with its inhabitents almost like they were real people. More often then not I find myself feeling guilty, or devious as I made plots for my own evil deeds. Fallout, either as a series or by itself, is a game of the decade, and with its current price, you'd be an idiot to pass it up. War may never change... but fallout? Its a new story every time you start, and its an adventure where you choose the results. No amount of words can do this game justice, and I wish I had connected the game through steam a long time ago.. because you would see over 2,000 hrs of time dedicated to such an enthralling experience. There are few games that have had such an impact, and for that reason it diserves a solid 10/10. And just like war.. that will never change.

content:
er 26, 2013
												Finished this a few days with 50-60 mods (mostly minor tweaks or aethetic changes), and I must say this game holds well even in 2013.  It took me some time to get into it, as I bought it in july and finished it in december, but once you do get the hang of the game, it's amazing.  Having played Skyrim and Oblivion previously, I will tell you Fallout is the superior game of both of them.  The setting, set in post apocalyptic D.C., is very immersive.  There's very few RPG's that are set in sci-fi or modern places, so this is definitely a gem to anyone who loves RPG but feels worn from fantasy themes.  However, like everything, nothing goes without some gripes.  As much I like guns in an RPG, the vanilla guns seem very lackluster.  I actually had to install weapon mods to add some more customizability.  Number 2 is the game is NOT optimized for quad core CPU's, something most computers have these days.  I can't think of the code from memory, but I had to put in some lines in my FALLOUT.INI to force the game to only use 2 of my cores or else the game would crash every 20 - 30 min. Number 3, is the vanilla character models, animations, and faces are terrible even for its time of release.  If you played Oblivion, those fugly faces are back so mods are essential if you want a decent looking character.   Number 4 --- too many super mutants -- enough said.  Now if you've gotten this far in this review, I will still say that the positives outweigh the negatives because I'm just trying to give everyone a good heads up, and if you managed to enjoy Oblivion or Skyrim, you can ignore half of these 'gripes'.  Everything else is good.  Overall it's a 9/10, so it's worth your money especially when it's $5-10.

content:
er 14, 2015
												First off, let me be clear; I  ADORE  this game. This was one of the first games I ever played on the 360, and to this day I absolutely love it. Never in my life have I played a game with so much replay value. While not perfect, it's still an amazing game and I would boot this game up any day.The reason why I'm giving this a thumbs down is because the PC version for this game is ONE OF THE WORST PORTS I HAVE EVER PLAYED. Never in my life have I seen something so buggy, so unstable, and SO ♥♥♥♥! Getting this game to run properly was a pain in the ♥♥♥ to begin with. It kept crashing whenever I would go to start up a new game. After much patience, I finally got it to get past the loading screen. So, were my troubles over? No. Of course not.Every so often, this game seems to just crash for no good reason. I've lost progress several times because of this, and it is the most infuriating thing I've ever had to put up with. Finally, my biggest complaint is that Alt+Tabbing out of the game pretty much ♥♥♥♥s it up. There were one or two times where this wasn't the case, but I still think this is horrible.Fallout on the PC is awesome, which I won't deny. There are SO MANY mods for this game that enhances your experience that you will not be able to get on console. But it's even more awesome when it  WORKS!  I've never had any problems like this that prevented me from playing the game when I owned it on console. Sure, there were bugs, like the occasional spazzing out of a ragdoll, but NEVER like this. If you haven't played this game before, please do, but for the love of God, just save yourself the headache and get it on console. The GOTY edition which has all 5 DLC packs should be about $25-$30 right now.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2012
												Fallout 3Where do i begin...This game took the semi-popular fallout franchise and revolutionised it in a way that must have seemed genius at the time although now we find ideas like that common-place by making Third/First person.For anyone who is new to the fallout universe, or just want a tad of backstory, here it is: Fallout 3 is based in the ruins of Washington DC which was destroyed in a war between America and China that ended with most of America turned into a nuclear wasteland. You have grown up in one of the many Vaults built by the government for what was thought to be protection against the war, but they where really built as a social experiment, with each vault being subjected to different experiments, from white noise to genetic mutations to never being allowed to open, all of which the inhabitants of these Vaults were unnaware of when they moved in.Now to the game its self. Fallout has pulled of the wasteland feel so well, from the survival to the ruins to all the strange and just down right wrong enemys you'll face. It has a great soundtrack based around the 50s-60s era which adds a strangely happy tone to the mood. The graphics are nothing special, but take into consideration how old it is. The weapons system just adds to the wasteland feel, with having to find ammo in the wasteland, and having to fix your weapons if the get to worn out. The most iconic part of this game is the armour, i mean just look at the game art, already you see a set of impressive armour, which just makes people to want it more.Alright lets wrap this up. Overall this game was groundbreaking when it came out, and to this day its still fun to return to the great DC ruins once more for another adventure, and isn't that what makes a game great? the ability to replay the game with the same enthusiasm as if you where playing it for your first time again. This game has shown me the greatest part of a nuclear Apocolypse, and that is... Adventure.9.5/10-=LevitatingBacon=-

content:
er 11, 2013
												Fallout 3 is a wonderful change into 3-D. I found some of the character animations a little stiff, but nothing too bad. I enjoyed a lot of the comedy within the game, with all the 50's goodness on a perfect America. A lot of the decisions didn't make a difference in most of the dialogue options, Which is a let down, but when it did I was happy that my choice actually mattered. The shooting in this game is down right broken without leveling up your skills, unless you use V.A.T.S for most of your combat. After I got my small-gun skill to about 90 the combat was a lot more enjoyable. I found most of the wasteland, just boring to look at with nothing interesting happening other than some enemies here or there, but maybe that's the point. I think some weather or something would have been nice. The story starts off rather slow and uninteresting, but gets a lot better nearing the end of the game. The music didn't standout for me, unlike The Elderscrolls series (This isn't talking about the music on the radio, Which I didn't even know you could listen to on your pip-boy until after I finished the game). Over-all I really did enjoy the game and would recommend this game to anyone a fan of The Elderscrolls series or post-apocalyptic games. I do want to add this game crashes A LOT, but I was able to get through the game just fine without being set back a whole lot, thanks to it's auto-saving.4/5 - Wonderful

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												Fallout 3 is definitely one of the best game i've ever played, I must have spent over 400 + hours on that game and I'm still not bored of it, there is just so much stuff to do that you end up playing over and over again. There is a large variety of guns, melee weapons, objects to collect, quests, creatures, NPCs, clothes etc.. There is also a lot of areas to explore in which most of the time feels new and fresh, you can even have a house that you can add stuff and themes in. But what makes this game really amazing is the ability to mod it, there is just so much awesome mods to add to this game, and its all free! The game itself takes about 60h minimum if you want to do everything in the game, and another 30h + with the DLCs. The story is also really interesting. And of course like other Bethesda games, you can customize your character to your liking, such as choosing his or her name, gender, appearances etc.. The game also has replay value since you can choose what kind of person you are. You can be a hero that saves lives and kills Super Mutants, or be a psycho killer that blows up towns and kill for caps, your choice! There is also a leveling system with special perks for your character and skills developement, which i thing is kind of a must have these days, especially in an RPG. The only downsides that I would give to this game are the weird bugs and glitches and the numerous crashes that you will encounter, and the kind of crappy animations, in which of course can be fixed with mods. The DLC were not that great in my opinion, don't get me wrong they're still worth it, but they're just not as interesting as they could have been. And that also occurs with the companions that can follow the character, exept for a small backstories, they dont have any side quests and they are not that interesting.Goods: + Lots of loot like weapons and objects, to sell or to put in your house. + Lots of customization for your character and your home. + Level up system with special perks and skill development. + Lots of quests and areas to explore. Interesting story. + Over 60 hours of gameplay with a bonus of 30 hours with the DLCs.+ Can save whenever you want and load the game at exactly where you last saved. + The ability of moding the game, which allows you to add whatever you want in the game really.+ Lots of interesting NPCs to interact within which most feels unique and different. + Insane replay value due to mods. + Lots of creature and enemies to kill and that feels unique and different.Bads:- Not so interesting but still worth it DLCs (in my opinion).- Lots of bug, glitches and crashes (especially when playing with mods).- Companions that are not really interesting (in my opinion).- Crappy and unnatural animations (but can be better with mods).Overall, I would really recommend this game to everyone that wants a good RPG with guns, gore and babes, and that want to go on a long adventure that will most likely, never end. Definitely worth the 19.99$ for the GOTY (Game of the Year) edition with all the DLCs included.Final Verdict:8/10 (not moded).Great Game!10/10 (with the good mods). Legendary!Recommended with a Badass seal of approval!!!!

												War, War never changes. But Bethesda has.When Fallout 4 Launched, those who survived did so in Fallout 3. When the steam reviews rolled out the community set out across the ruins of the old franchise to build new mods. As 48 hours past, what had been the Fallout community, united underneath the flag of the New Fallout Republic, dedicated to old Fallout values of non-voice acted protaganists and actual RPG elements. As the Republic grew, so did it's age, modders spread east seeking better storylines and intelligent speech options the dryer mercilless expanse of the Fallout franchise could offer. They returned with tales of a game untouched by Fallout 4's terrible launch that has scorched the rest of the world and a great wall of its mods spanning the Fallout Nexus site. The NFR mobilized its army and sent it east to occupy the Fallout 4's steam page and restore it to negetive reviews that actually made sense. but across the Nexus another society had arrisen under a diffrent flag. A vast army of Fanboys who had never played an RPG in their life. Forged from the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ communities of COD and just about every EA game, Todd's Legion. 4 days have passed since the Republic held the steam page just barrely against the Legion's fake possitive reviews. The Fanboys did not retreat. across the Nexus the legion gathers strength. Dialoge options release, re-textures come out. Through it all Fallout: New Vegas, stayed open for buissness under the control of it's mysterious overseers obsidian entertainment and their army of rehabilitated fanboys.You are a reviewer hired by IGN to deliver a review for Fallout 4. What seemed like a simple 10/10 has taken a turn for the worst. IGN representitive 1: You got the review you wanted, so pay up.Todd Howard: You're crying about a review pally.IGN representitive 2: Guess who's community is wakin' up over here?Todd Howard: Time to cash in.IGN representitive 1: Will you get it over with?Todd Howard: Maybe EA kills franchises without looking the community in the face, but I ain't EA. You made your last honest review kid. Sorry you got twisted up in this buisness. From where your review stands, it must seem like an 7/10 run of bad luck. Truth is... The Franchise was rigged from the start.ASteam Community ReviewFallout: New Franchise

content:
9, 2015
												This game is truly amazing and I am greatly saddened by the fact that it's user reviews are brought down to only "very positive", just because people are too indolent to try and solve simple problems. Disregard every negative review as they are ALL complaints about easy-to-fix problems that I will explain in greater detail at the end of this review.Fallout 3 has managed to set standards in both the FPS and RPG genres, and is possibly my favourite game of all time. Very few games come anywhere close to F3 in lore, atmosphere, combat, story, and overall gameplay, and none are on par in all of those elements combined.Lore - the fallout franchise as a whole has some of the most developed and interesting lore that I've experienced from a video game. Though, managing to incorperate it without requiring the player to have played previous games is something that F3 has done incredibly well.Atmosphere - Being set in a post-apocalyptic US, 200 years after nuclear war with China, F3 has done a fantastic job at making a nearly desolate nuclear wasteland something worth exploring. That combined with with themes from a 50's, anti-communist, nuclear, technologically advanced America makes F3 something truly unique and incredibly enjoyable to dwell in and explore.Combat - F3's combat was truly revolutionary for its time. The mechanic found in V.A.T.S was something never seen before and many mechanics in current games get their inspiration from it. Nothing compares to an intense gunfight whilst you have mid-20th century swing and blues playing from your Pip-Boy.Story - Many have complained that F3's story is too linear, and admittedly the main storyline is fairly linear, but the main quests aren't the only story. There is just as much emphasis on side quests as there is on the main one, and side quests often have a lot of decisions to be made. It's in the rest of the quests that you decide how you want to play and what kind of person you want to be.Gameplay - After leaving the vault, you are constantly progressing. Fighting harder enemies, getting better weapons and armour, and increasing your various skills. But it never gets repetitive. While you still have quests to complete, and there are many, gameplay will never become blasé.The complaints I have with this game are few, and all can be fixed with F3's amazing modding community. So I will include links to the mods that fix all of these problems.No ADS - The ability to aim down your sight is one that seems to be in nearly every FPS, so it is somewhat surprising that F3 doesn't have it. Instead, you get a slight zoom by pressing what would be the ADS key. Luckily there are modders that have fixed this. http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/6938/?Micro stutter - This slight stutter is one that has plagued both the Fallout and Elder Scrolls games for a long time. A fix can be found here http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/8886/?Sprinting - It can be annoying when you need to traverse a great distance but you're stuck with that slow vanilla running. It seems odd that you wouldn't be able to sprint, but of course, we have the modding community to fix this. http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1854/?Now for the problems that keep all the negative reviewers from enjoying the game.If you press play on the first window and it closes without launching the game, more likely than not, you do not have Games for Windows Live installed. This is required to run F3.Games for Windows Live: http://download.gfwl.xboxlive.com/content/gfwl-public/redists/production/xliveredist.msiAnother problem that people have is that the game will occasionally freeze. As you have seen on the store page for Fallout 3, it is not optimized for Windows 7 and 8. I've been using the Fallout Script Extender(FOSE) for a while and I've experienced no freezes.FOSE: http://fose.silverlock.org/This may help too.Better Game Performance: http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/13520/?Overall, Fallout 3 is absolutely fantastic and is one of the greatest experiences I've had with a video game. 95/100

content:
22, 2016
												Why is Fallout 3 among the best games ever made in a nut shell? It lets you live out a fascinating story in a familiar but ruined world. It paints and charts the life of an imaginary you and lets you act in a way that makes you feel personally invested in the outcome of its story. The characters all feel alive and important. Game play wise it is solid and easily understood enough to carry the story to the end with epic detail, impact, and flare. ProsEverything about it.ConsThis game could only have been better by adding more. More monsters, npcs, stats, and maps. It could have lived on MMO style and possibly gone multi-player. The PC version is buggy and does suffer from crashing at times. It hasn't hit me personally much, and I save often.  Really, it should be updated to Window 10 for the crazy number of copies sold.Bottom line: If you don't own Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition and you like games, movies, or stories, find a way to play it immediately.

content:
0, 2015
												The Fallout Franchise raised the bar for all the Post-apocalyptic games to come.A lot of games make a huge deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation.You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your post-apocalyptic journey through the Washington DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing and allso replaying and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.Oh Yeah!? This is prabably the only game that gives a player the freedom to put a live grandes in someones pocket.

content:
ber 15, 2015
												Since Fallout 4 is on the horizon, I decided to return to the series. I must say that I have really mixed feelings about the game, but like the VATS system (and overall gameplay) in Fallout Vegas better. (Loved the game when it came out as there were fewer open-world games back then).  Fallout 3 is much more challenging, in good and bad (poorly designed) ways. It's one of the last of a dying bread of challenging story-rich (somewhat) ARPGs -- before they become so-called "dumbed down." Though for me, I found the game tedious in parts. If you're good with "shooters" and like micro-managing your ammo, you'll probably like the game more. If you want to get into the Fallout story, it's probably a good place to start though, unless you're willing to play the oldies. It is more glitch-free than Vegas (if you read how to get it to work with Win 7-8 (I don't know about 10). Play for the Brotherhood of Steel perspective/armor if nothing else. If you don't like to work too hard at your games -- try Vegas and its overpowered companions instead. That said, I've never modded the game and such may make the game more likable.

												Since Fallout 4 is on the horizon, I decided to return to the series. I must say that I have really mixed feelings about the game, but like the VATS system (and overall gameplay) in Fallout Vegas better. (Loved the game when it came out as there were fewer open-world games back then).  Fallout 3 is much more challenging, in good and bad (poorly designed) ways. It's one of the last of a dying bread of challenging story-rich (somewhat) ARPGs -- before they become so-called "dumbed down." Though for me, I found the game tedious in parts. If you're good with "shooters" and like micro-managing your ammo, you'll probably like the game more. If you want to get into the Fallout story, it's probably a good place to start though, unless you're willing to play the oldies. It is more glitch-free than Vegas (if you read how to get it to work with Win 7-8 (I don't know about 10). Play for the Brotherhood of Steel perspective/armor if nothing else. If you don't like to work too hard at your games -- try Vegas and its overpowered companions instead. That said, I've never modded the game and such may make the game more likable.

content:
30, 2016
												War, War never changes. But Bethesda has.When Fallout 4 Launched, those who survived did so in Fallout 3. When the steam reviews rolled out the community set out across the ruins of the old franchise to build new mods. As 48 hours past, what had been the Fallout community, united underneath the flag of the New Fallout Republic, dedicated to old Fallout values of non-voice acted protaganists and actual RPG elements. As the Republic grew, so did it's age, modders spread east seeking better storylines and intelligent speech options the dryer mercilless expanse of the Fallout franchise could offer. They returned with tales of a game untouched by Fallout 4's terrible launch that has scorched the rest of the world and a great wall of its mods spanning the Fallout Nexus site. The NFR mobilized its army and sent it east to occupy the Fallout 4's steam page and restore it to negetive reviews that actually made sense. but across the Nexus another society had arrisen under a diffrent flag. A vast army of Fanboys who had never played an RPG in their life. Forged from the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ communities of COD and just about every EA game, Todd's Legion. 4 days have passed since the Republic held the steam page just barrely against the Legion's fake possitive reviews. The Fanboys did not retreat. across the Nexus the legion gathers strength. Dialoge options release, re-textures come out. Through it all Fallout: New Vegas, stayed open for buissness under the control of it's mysterious overseers obsidian entertainment and their army of rehabilitated fanboys.You are a reviewer hired by IGN to deliver a review for Fallout 4. What seemed like a simple 10/10 has taken a turn for the worst. IGN representitive 1: You got the review you wanted, so pay up.Todd Howard: You're crying about a review pally.IGN representitive 2: Guess who's community is wakin' up over here?Todd Howard: Time to cash in.IGN representitive 1: Will you get it over with?Todd Howard: Maybe EA kills franchises without looking the community in the face, but I ain't EA. You made your last honest review kid. Sorry you got twisted up in this buisness. From where your review stands, it must seem like an 7/10 run of bad luck. Truth is... The Franchise was rigged from the start.ASteam Community ReviewFallout: New Franchise

content:
er 10, 2015
												I bought this game but I'll not go through the mistake of giving Bethesda my money again. First, the game isn't optimized for Windows 7, as stated in the Store Page, but this is so ♥♥♥♥ing stupid I can't even. They release the game and give 0 ♥♥♥♥s about the new systems where people will try to run their game (that isn't even that old to begin with)? So, I have to go through the trouble of fixing the game myself so I can play it. And what a game.It was kinda fun at first but it grew boring and repetitive pretty quickly: same scenarios, same enemies all the time, same "press V and aim for the head and blow their heads off quickly to be done with that" over and over again, with no new ♥♥♥♥ whatsoever to help make the combat more interesting as the game progressed. The side-quests are boring and if you only go for the main-quests you'll be done in a few hours. The map is gigantic with many "points of interest" you can find, but it's pretty ♥♥♥♥ing the same desert over and over again with the same monsters and with absolutely nothing to do. I mean it. The side-quests, main-quests and DLC quests can't even cover one third of the whole map. You're left with no motivation to go exploring the rest of the game since there's nothing to do there and you will be bothered by enemies over and over again and engage in dull combat. Again.The characters are so ♥♥♥♥ing basic I could probably kill everyone and not feel a thing. Actually the best part of this game is killing innocent people (although I always went for good karma so I saved the game before killing everyone and loaded it when I was satisfied). Your father has Liam Neeson's voice so that's cool though.The other plus would be how your choices affect the world, although I couldn't care less about the world and its inhabitants in the game so that numbs down the weight of the choices considerably. The character building is kinda good, but if you like challenge then this probably isn't the game for you since I usually ♥♥♥♥ up while building characters in RPGs, but Fallout 3 was so easy it was starting to get annoying. Perhaps in higher difficulties it's really challenging? Dunno, didn't go through the trouble of trying it out.I believe the worst part is that two years after this pile of trash came out, they made the same game again. LITERALLY the same game. New Vegas is basically Fallout 3 but with cowboy hats. And the game is yellowish instead of greenish. The graphics are the same the gameplay is the same EVERYTHING is the same. Now we have Fallout 4 and guess what? IT'S THE SAME THING AGAIN. The graphics are better, but they're still far behind other games nowadays, and Bethesda just ends up charging the highest of prices I've ever seen on Steam, as if they deserved it.The only reason I have 40+ hours in this game is because I ended up buying the GOTY edition and felt like I had to go through the DLCs as well since I already paid for this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but that's it.Don't buy this game.Stop giving Bethesda your money, they couldn't give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about you.

content:
23, 2015
												The hallowed memories of yesteryears games makes the Fallout tradition a challenging project to have undertaken. Bethesda has not released a perfect game, but there is no doubt in my mind that this is indeed a worthy heir to the Fallout lineage. What it has lost by leaving the 3rd person isometric view it has gained back 100 fold by an amazingly detailed world, storylines that go far beyond simple lines of dialog, and many different paths for the player to choose. There is in fact far more content than any single playthrough needs to experience, promising greater replayability.A masterpiece.

content:
1, 2015
												This review comes at a bit of a strange time as I first played Fallout 3 years ago. Then I tried to get it to work with my current rig and it wouldn't despite numerous attempts at fixing it. I eventually gave up and moved on to playing Fallout Vegas. I did like Vegas (and still haven't completed it) but found I had strong memories of Fallout 3 and kept judging Vegas by its predecessor. Then recently a miracle happened and I found a fix that got 3 working again. I have never been able to put my finger on it but Vegas had something missing from it which Fallout 3 had. I think its a combination of things really. For a start I found the whole setting and atmosphere of Fallout 3 to be way more apocalyptic than Vegas. Thats probably down to the twisted wreckage of old highways that dot the horizon and vast skeletal shells of long dead cities. It really makes you feel that something extremely bad happened to the world (which of course did). The music varies and sometimes can be hauntingly eerie.There are a ton of side missions and of course the main story. All that before you even touch the DLC's. The game has many good storylines with some that force you to decide what kind of wastelander you are going to be,With our world supposedly on the verge of its next extinction event and heightened tensions between some super powers its never been a better time to play fallout and visit the maybe world of tomorrow.Fallout 4 is on its way. It looks great so far but I expect it will be compared to the earlier games such as Fallout 3.A most definite 10 / 10 classic title that should be in every serious gamers library.

												Ridiculous Amounts of FunI purchased this game on a whim. After playing FO3:GOTY on my PS3, I was curious to see what it would be like to play on the PC. I was not disappointed. I had some trouble running the game at first, as this is not optimized for Win10, but after some fiddling around I was able to play with great stability. The only thing I didn't really care for was the lengthy intro. This game is a great way to kill time, and sit back. If your specs are good this game will look amazing. If your like me, and prefer preformance, this will look even better. The combat system is simple, no different than FNV. V.A.T.S. is OP if your stats are right, the weapons and armor are balanced, along with the items. And the soundtrack is nothing to scoff at. There are many ways to play the story. You can play as a theif by stealing everything in sight (say bye-bye to your karma!), you can play as a hero, a monster, and much more. Score:-Gameplay: 8/10-Sound: 7/10-Combat: 10/10-Graphics: 9/10-DLC: 8/10-Overall Score: 8/10On to the technical stuff. All I own is a Surface Pro 2, and some accessories for it. So of course gameplay isn't going to be stellar. I am posting these as a reference for anyone who would like to see what my specs are compared to theirs. content:
9, 2015
												Since Fallout 4 is nearing it's release date I'll release a review for Fallout 3. Now before I start I'll end the common debate most people have when they want to start playing the Fallout series... DO I PURCHASE FALLOUT NEW VEGAS OR FALLOUT 3? Well since I have both I'll write down the pros and the cons of both games so bear with me for now.Fallout 3 Pros+ Very story rich, tells you about the Lone Wanderer and how he/she was born and raised.+ Is a very beautiful game in my personal opinion.+ Very nice radio that will keep you entertained while travelling the Washington wasteland.+ Multiple endings so you can keep playing this game over and over.+ THREE DOG AND DOGMEAT.+ Very big atmosphere that's entirely yours to explore.+ VATS is a wonderful gameplay mechanic that is introduced in Fallout 3.+ Karma meter which makes you feel like you're an actual person instead of just a mindless killer.Fallout 3 Cons- No iron sight aiming.- Not optimized for Windows 7 or later. (This doesn't mean that it's unplayable on Windows 7 it's just that you have to modify the game files and that's really time consuming. Took me about 7 hours to fix Fallout 3 for my Windows 7 computer.)- Somewhat small level cap (20, but can be increased with the Broken-Steel DLC)- Very short main story line.- Companions AREN'T invincible.- Doesn't have an indicatior for when weapons are really worn thus making them more likely to jam.Now that I've talked a bit about Fallout 3 I'll talk about the pros and cons of Fallout: New VegasFallout: New Vegas Pros+ Iron sight aiming.+ VATS is a returning feature in Fallout: New Vegas.+ Companions are invincible.+ Hardcore mode is an option for all you hardcore fans out there.+ Runs fine on Windows 7 and later (managed to run it on my terrible computer at a stable 60 FPS.)+ A better radio than Fallout 3 (in my personal opinion.)+ Weapon modification is an option.+ REX.+ You're in Las Vegas, what more do I need to say?+ Some fun gambling to do in The Strip if that's your thing.+ Increasing level cap if you have DLC installed. (Increases by 5 for each DLC, 30 is the base level cap.)+ Very big and beautiful world, but not as big as Fallout 3.+ The Kings.+ No karma requirements to recruit companions.+ Reputation for factions.Fallout: New Vegas- Tons of invisible walls over the Mojave Wasteland.- No back story AT ALL about our player character: The Courier.- Very limited story endings.- A lot of walking must be done unless you have found some places to fast travel to. - TONS of bugs.- A.I isn't as good as in Fallout 3.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now for the review of Fallout 3: You start off as a baby that is newly born. You then have a time skip to you as a toddler, and another to when you're 10, and 15. Finally when you're 18 the game really starts. This game is beautiful the moment you step out of Vault 101 and see the sunlight for the first time. It's not too far into the game when you meet Dogmeat, a fan favourite companion loved by all. During this time you are already free to do as you please and explore the Washington wastelands. This game is entirely based by your actions so it's amazing that you get to choose how the game will end. Will you be a villian feared all across the wasteland? Or will you be the guardian angel of the wasteland? If you want to find out... BUY THIS GAME! (Ps. took me about an hour to write, enjoy)

												My review is NOT based on the quality of the game.  Let's be clear; Fallout 3 is one of the greatest games ever made.  It's up there with things like Half Life.My review is for this specific version of the game, which happens to be unplayable.My computer is an i5 3.4ghz with 16g ram and a GTX660 operating on Windows 7.  The game freezes every 5 mins or so.  I've been through multiple solutions from rewriting the .ini file to downloading patches and supposed fixes.  I would still give this game a thumbs up if any of those options worked, but they haven't.  I still can't play the game because I have to alt+ctrl+del and force close the program every few minutes.  A game from Steam should be playable right out of the box, especially a relatively recent (and massively popular) game like Fallout 3.  Steam really screwed the pooch on this one.Until they fix the freezing, I can't recommend that you buy this game.

er 29, 2015
												A poorly written, poorly coded mess. I'd prefer Van Buren be made over this any day. This game is a terrible FPS and shouldn't be considered an RPG. If you want a good Fallout game, play Fallout New Vegas, Fallout 1, and Fallout 2. You should probably pirate those games to avoid Burchthesda gaining more money. I'll be fair though. Here are the Pro's and Con's of this game.PROS: - Switching from Isometric turn based mechanics to FPS style mechanics. This creates a more interactive world, where you can see things up close and feel very immersed, but at the cost of creating a slightly less fallout-like experience.- Laser weapons now have a beam instead of shooting a projectile.- World is large, so more to explore.- Certain designs were improved.CONS:- Badly redesigned weapons.- Awful writing. Just awful.- Very bad glitched engine.- Faces look bad. And I'm talking REAL bad. You'll notice it very soon.- Perishable foods somehow manage to survive 200 years?- Brotherhood of Steel for some reason turns into the Wasteland police instead of greedy technology hoarders. - Takes place on east coast. Screw the east coast. Seriously. Fallout should always be on the west coast. - Butchers classic Fallout lore.- And most of all, it isn't an RPG. It's a terribly made shooter with RPG elements that aren't taken seriously and can easily be abused by any dumbsh!t to become a pseudo god by level 15.

												It's got some nice gameplay and it's generally quite fun. You can find yourself wandering around the wastes for hours, never getting bored.However, it does have some issues:- The random encounters can be annoting if you're not expecting them, especially the Enclave ones. - The lack of aiming down sights annoys me and makes it hard to aim, but some people may think otherwise or appreciate the challenge.- Unfortunately, Bethesda dropped the ball when it came to the plot, which is silly most of the time and stupid at its worst. The only good thing about the plot is Liam Neeson. However, I would still recommend Fallout 3 for its wonderful gameplay and the fact that you can play it again and again and never get bored.

												I first played Fallout 3 in 2010, on an xbox 360, I was blown away and an obsession was born in me.The games story compared to New Vegas, isn't the best, but still amazing, I loved every second of it.I played for 100+ hours and then a friend gave me his GOTY with all the DLC, I thought I was going to die. number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2014
												Fallout 3. This is a game that will, most of the time, suck you in with its amazing atmosphere and environments. I say most of the time because, just like the Steam notice says there, it's not optimized for Windows 7. Now I have Windows 7, and I fully played through all the content in this game, and what I believe they're trying to say with that is that this game has a bunch of performance issues. Fallout 3 loves to crash. A lot. As in, it made me press the quicksave button all the time so I'd make sure I wouldn't lose as much progressas I potentially could. However, I did play through everything, and I loved it. In fact, this is the second time that I've played through everything in Fallout 3. I just love the game so much that even the regular crash couldn't stop me.The very first part of the game is so well done, very immersive and eases you into the game proper nicely. Don't expect amazing shooting mechanics, while it does have FPS mechanics (you'll never used third person camera because of how bad it is for combat) you don't play it for the shooting. You play it instead for the RPG elements, the storytelling, and the impeccable atmosphere the Wasteland offers you. It's grim, it's gory, it's gritty, it is a complete hellhole on a destroyed post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. Many of the landmarks that characterize D.C in the real world are very well replicated here in its ruined and wrecked glory. The Fallout universe itself is a joy to be in, with its 50's/futuristic quirks, power armors, aliens, big guns that really go BOOM, and freaky mutations. The game did give me quite a few jumpscares when I was caught unawares by some of the wildlife. The V.A.T.S system is awesome as you pick your favorite body part and shoot, complete with guts and gore flying everywhere as your enemies die. Good stuff.The inevitable question when it comes to this game is: "Is it better than New Vegas or is it the other way around?" I would say that even though I slightly prefer New Vegas, both are worth playing anyway because it shows both Bethesda and Obsidian's strong (and weak) points. And both are good games in their own right.Bethesda made Fallout 3. And what makes Bethesda great are both its sidequests (which are always more interesting than the main story itself) and its attention to detail in its environments. They love to litter the landscape with information, each containing a small story or information explaining why that skeleton's standing in that bathroom, for example. And sometimes it doesn't, all it shows you, all it needs, is the scenery itself that tells the story for you. This makes exploration really engaging and fun because things rarely feel they're copypasted (except the subway tunnels but there's only so much you can do to make a ruined subway tunnel stand out, though some do stand out anyway).The quests themselves have multiple solutions and most of the time offer choice, like a good RPG should, and trust me, you can do some extreme stuff in these which will literally change the landscape, but then again, these choices and this engaging writing are severely lacking in the main quest itself, which is clichéd and ultimately really linear. I prefer Obsidian's writing overall, so New Vegas wins out on Fallout 3 for me there. Fallout 3 though, like any good sandbox RPG should do, which New Vegas does not, is allow you to keep playing after the actual ending. In NV's defense though, there are so many endings that it would be hell to program into, but still, it's something worth keeping an eye out for.Fallout 3's the oldest game of the two, so it will, gameplay-wise, lack a few features NV adds in later on.Like any modern Bethesda RPG, Fallout 3 adds much needed mod support which makes the PC version by far the best, allowing you to fix many of its faults, and become an even better experience than it already is. Though I'd recommend just sticking to performance mods the first time around, as some of these mods can change the game dramatically.The DLC for the game itself is a bit hit and miss in my opinion. DLCs like Broken Steel which let you keep playing the game after its conclusion, or Point Lookout and The Pitt, which add areas of their own with stuff to do are great, but Anchorage and Zeta, though unique, don't add to the game all that much, and you wouldn't feel like something's missing if these never came out.All in all, I totally recommend this game, lots of RPG goodness and with mod support, can have you keep coming for more.

												the first fallout game i played, Fallout 3 incredible main story, awsome side quests, and massive nonlieniar atmosphiric open world make this one of the best games i've ever played. After playing both new vegas and fallout 4, i found that in terms of story, atmosphere ,and side quests, fallout 3 is the clear winner dispite in my opinion not being as overall good as fallout 4 (but still 500x better then new vegas, seriously i have no idea what obsidian was thinking when they implemented ceasars legion or thought that the game had an acceptable main quest.) The only true flaw i find in fallout 3 is the actual writing and dialoge that goes with its incredible story, at times its has that nice simple feel to it that might remind you of dialoge beween saturday morning action cartoons (childish, but at the same time awsome,) other times it just is downright childish and rather lazy (seriously, one of the many ways to kill the main villan is to convince him that he is insane, and he just kills himself, yeah its very hard to pass the speech check, but its still rather silly way to destroy a rather awsome villian.) Overall fallout 3 is a gameing masterpeice, combining rpg elements from the first 2 games with (at the time of its relese) modern fps mechanics to bring a new standard to the fallout franchise, a standard that set the foundation for fallout new vegas and Fallout 4.

content:
8, 2016
												It has been a while since I have actually sat down for a playthrough, however the times that I have were unforgettable moments. This game admittedly has a fairly short campaign once the player is aware of the certain courses that need to be taken; this does not limit replayablility, however. Although the campaign itself is fairly short and straightforward, the gameplay is a whole separate story. With Hub locations across the map, several factions to join, as well as a myriad of perks to choose from as the game progresses, different quest outcomes based on your responses, and a wealth of quests included in the main campaign, side campaigns, quests in add-on packs, as well as the occasional single side mission.  There was never really a dull moment for me in this game. Occasionally the game will minimize with no hope of re-opening, but I am also running on Windows 10, which is a fairly easy scapegoat at this point.  I only have 73 logged hours, but I have so many uncounted hours within my Xbox playthroughs (I happened to acquire that version for free) and I have fallen in love with the game and franchise.  This game will not disappoint.  I give this game 10 Bobbleheads out of 10.

content:
2, 2015
 To people who can't run it on windows 7/8 It's literally one google search away on how to fix this. For all problems: http://steamcommunity.com//sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149946772/Just update Games For Windows Live with the link within the fallout 3 fixes post above and start up issues should be fixed for Win 8 users. Freezing/crashing within the game will usually be fixed by doing this simple .ini edit.Go to the Fallout.ini file in Documents/my games/Fallout3Use Ctrl+F and search for bUseThreadedAIChange bUseThreadedAI=0 to bUseThreadedAI=1Then add iNumHWThreads=2 directly after this.Yes not really a review but if everyone followed this guide there would be a significantly smaller amount of negative reviews for this game.

content:
y 22, 2016
												My stats are slightly confusing as they don't seem to count timing correctly. I must have played about 50-60 hours by now or so which is fair enough to make a review. As reference I finished the game once with a few side quests (about 30-40 hours, and made another build to do a casual powerrun which finished the game in 10-11 hours. Faster is possible obviously but you'd miss the entire idea behind the Fallout games if you did.Compared to New Vegas, Fallout 3 is a lot more straightforward as less speech options really determine how the game flows, however at the same time more survival/radiation build. You get less traces on your map, less evident companions, you're more left to yourself basically. Which is nice too, it's just different from New Vegas.Of course you'll always have Three Dog and a friendly reminder that not everyone wants to set the world on fire which is conforting in its own right.All in all, a very decent RPG game that I can fully advice to anyone.BTW, if you only have a dualcore but you have windows 7, the game will run just fine ;)

er 31, 2015
												Running it on Windows 10 on ultra graphics very smooth solid 60fps I can achieve higher frames but I choice to use vsync because of screen tearing. And HDR looks sweet. step 1 modify FALLOUT.ini(documents->mygames->fallout3) file if you have more then a dual coreunder general change the following lines of codechange bUseThreadedAI=0 to bUseThreadedAI=1add line of code under generaliNumHWThreads=2step 2 download/install games for live on windows websitestep 3 download/install fallout live disabler from nexus modstep 4 change both launcher and exe compatibility mode to windows xp sp3 and run as adminstratorstep 5 Make sure Drivers are updated thanks to nvidia community that was easy I have a 980GTXm 4gb gpustep 6  play the best game ever made.On a lighter noteNuka Cola Recipe IRL1/3 coca cola1/3 mountain dew1/3 creme sodaenjoy the refreshing drink! because in total I played this on xbox 360 120 Hours and now I will be doing it again this time on my brand new MSI GT72 Maxed out Gaming Laptop until that is they work the bugs out in Fallout 4. I played and beat every bethesda game every sidequest every achievement I might as well work there.I plan in the future 3d printing my own pipboy 3000 its easy the 3d files are online and if you don't have a 3d printer just use 3d hubs it will set you back about 150 bucks.And to make your own nuka cola bottles are easy just print lables onto sticker paper, cut out and take a coca cola bottle(scrap labeling is optional) the mexican cola works good to and fill it full of mountain dew voltage goto radioshack get a resistor(use a led resistor calc online for what ever led you buy) Mine was red blue brown gold, battery holder for a watch battery cr2032, mini switch and uv led (solder it all together) to make your own nuka cola quantum. I can't sell any of this because you know copyrights. lol If you need a good cap to seal it use a twist off cap thats not damaged. theres even designs for the sticker for the lid if you want to protect the sticker use a polypropylene or clear epoxyThanks For ReadingBuy this game if you havent!The Fallout Anthology Package is the way to go. It comes with a mini nuke. There is an empty slot for Fallout 4.

content:
er 22, 2015
												This was my second playthrough. First time was in 2009. All told I think I have about 250+ hours into FO3. The first time through I was about 100 hours in before I finished the main story. This time I finished the main story in about 20 hours. I think it felt better this time to stay on track before going out and exploring the wastes. I mean, I needed to help my dad! Last time I was so distracted and I think I even forgot about helping him. This time I played on hard. It was a lot of fun, and way too easy after level 18 or so.. I still ended up always looting too much and being overloaded. Games with a lot of stuff to loot and keep track of really help me see my obsessive nature. This time I didn't use VATS so much, and I got to experience what a poor shooter the game is. The weapons suck and are always breaking. So early on I put all my skill points into repair skills. I loved having well-maintainted gear, and it made it easier to immediately make use of stuff that was loading me down.The Pitt was the most memorable for me.I felt so conflicted by the quest's ultimate decision. Am I wrong for choosing to side with the ex-brotherhood dude despite him enslaving people? I trusted his ultimate intentions, and his vision seemed more broad than the slave's. I supposed he could possibly have the means to carry out his intentions and that maybe the wastes would benefit. The slave seemed to be acting mostly out of anger, and he lacked information to tell me why I should help him. But.. He was a slave. I naturally wanted to help him.Mothership Zeta was maybe 10% interesting and the rest was just mundane and boring. And why where some of those alien dudes so so so tough? That was crazy.Operation Anchorage was nice because the simulator had blue sky.  The color was nice. The story was easy.Would I recommend a second playthrough?I don't know.. I had fun. But I think it was better back in the day. This time, I enjoyed more the way that I played it. The order of the quests made it much more interesting.

content:
y 22, 2016
												My stats are slightly confusing as they don't seem to count timing correctly. I must have played about 50-60 hours by now or so which is fair enough to make a review. As reference I finished the game once with a few side quests (about 30-40 hours, and made another build to do a casual powerrun which finished the game in 10-11 hours. Faster is possible obviously but you'd miss the entire idea behind the Fallout games if you did.Compared to New Vegas, Fallout 3 is a lot more straightforward as less speech options really determine how the game flows, however at the same time more survival/radiation build. You get less traces on your map, less evident companions, you're more left to yourself basically. Which is nice too, it's just different from New Vegas.Of course you'll always have Three Dog and a friendly reminder that not everyone wants to set the world on fire which is conforting in its own right.All in all, a very decent RPG game that I can fully advice to anyone.BTW, if you only have a dualcore but you have windows 7, the game will run just fine ;)

content:
2, 2015
 To people who can't run it on windows 7/8 It's literally one google search away on how to fix this. For all problems: http://steamcommunity.com//sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149946772/Just update Games For Windows Live with the link within the fallout 3 fixes post above and start up issues should be fixed for Win 8 users. Freezing/crashing within the game will usually be fixed by doing this simple .ini edit.Go to the Fallout.ini file in Documents/my games/Fallout3Use Ctrl+F and search for bUseThreadedAIChange bUseThreadedAI=0 to bUseThreadedAI=1Then add iNumHWThreads=2 directly after this.Yes not really a review but if everyone followed this guide there would be a significantly smaller amount of negative reviews for this game.
