content:
7, 2015
												Fallout 3. Immersive, intriguing, and badass. The story is one of the best stories in gaming. I find it to be just as good a story as BioShock. You may hear,"Oh it's just you tryna find your dad. It's really not that interesting." To HELL with that. You need to actually expirience this game in order to truly and fully appreciate Fallout 3's story. Three issues I have with the game. Number one, the game will not work properly on Windows 7 or above. Now this CAN BE FIXED. If you cannot figure it out, message me because I want you to enjoy this game. Number two, the visuals are not impressive. This was to be expected with a huge open world RPG such as this. Like most other games, you can modify this game.  Taking the visuals to a whole 'nother level. It rivals SKYRIM and BIOSHOCK INFINITE. That said, you need a beefy graphics card to handle the visual mods. With advanced shaders, blue skies and better looking textures, this game looks phenomenal. I don't enjoy the fact that you have to modify the game to make it prettier, but what has to be done must be done. Having siad that, the game isn't unbearable vanilla. I said the visuals are not impressive, not that they are bad. Number three, Fallout has a reputation for being one of the BUGGIEST PIECES OF LOVELY ♥♥♥♥. It isn't as bad as DayZ but the fact that the two can even be compared is saddening to me. Fortunately, most common and random bugs disappear when playing on pc. They occasionally occur and most are easy fixes. Most. Crashing is eliminated with a 4gb patch and stuttering is solved with a simple mod. At long last you can enjoy your childhood once more at 60fps (good graphics card) and no crashing as it did on console. I rate 10/10 vanilla on PC, 9/10 on console and with mods 11/10. I would recommend this game a million times if I could.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
												The road so far......wasn't kind to me. It was full of loss and misery. Full of hopeless people and lost souls that stepped on this doomed wasteland.Yet, it wasn't only damnation that followed my steps. I found my father, my love Amata, a faithful companions... only to loose them the next second.If this was the road so far, what will follow it? I know you can't talk, my good, old, friend, dogmeat. Despite that, I know you can listen, you are the only one who does that. So, thank you, buddy.________________________After 95 hours I finally finished this unique game. It was a long journey that, sadly, or not, came to the conclusion.I have mixed feeling because I can not, but to notice, the flaws of this game.The combat is far from perfection. Constant invisible walls interfere in the shooting so that stealth and sniper headshot from a far is not an option. It is frustrating at times, but the VATS does a perfect job to overcome the combat flaws. It balances it.Writing of the main story. It's not good. It's average. It does the job to send you to a different locations and introduce the world, but that's it. I do like the small stories, though, which this world is packed to it's fullest and the enormous attention to detail. But the main plot... At the end, the feeling is that the bone was thrown and if we search enogh we can find it. In any case, sadly, it's not there. A mere feel of a presence of something epic is not what we want.Don't take me the wrong way. I like this game. It's good. Not perfect but good enough. There isn't any very good highlights but the mixture and huge diversity make this game a unique experience worth to check...if you push by yourself and force to go throw the tedious start that keept me aways the 2 past attempts to play Fallout 3.First 20 levels are a joy to play. You keep discovering new things and some quite memorable moments. A very simple details engage with a perfection to this unworthy world: A text based story about Grognak that you play on a terminal; Tranquility Lane; Princess who is secretly in love with the leader of Little Lamplight; Brother who got two naughty nightwear; A old man who I saved from suicide attempts.Despite the average writing of the main plot where it shines is in the clues of the past. There is no history in Fallout 3. Though, it creates an understanding of the past by the logs, terminals and documents. And it does the job like non other game up this date. The contradictive information, the vision of people of the those past events - at times I felt like archaeologist.There are a huge depth that you can completely ignore and focus on the aspects you like. Do whatever. The world is there. What do you gonna do in it?________________________It happened before and it will happen again.So many killed, so much destroyed... and yet it's not enough, it is never enough. Because war... war never changes.It is time, we need to go my friend. Our journey has just started.


Into the sunset. The last moment of my gameplay. 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: KyrDerz

content:
er 26, 2016
												I'm just getting my review out there now—I'm also one of those typical players who hasn't even made any progress since I [left the Vault and became a wanderererere going all over the place]I also decided I would review this game, as I've selected it for the 2016 Steam Awards; in the 'Game within a Game' category. Though, looking past what you might be thinking—the text-based game inside of Hubris Comics—this is obviously a game about harsh survival; in an even harsher, post-apocalyptic world with an amazing backstory to it [I can assume, as I've forementioned that I haven't made any progress with the game's story]It's a personal story for me, the idea of a 'Lone Wanderer'—a hero among the world that's left. It's amazing, and just so facinating to me. And the Karma aspect of the game really enhances the experience for us gamers, and there are way too many games out there nowadays that restrict you into playing a set character profile and stuff [looking at you, Fallout 4]. Sure, there aren't that many options in this game where you can customize your character, but, with the kind of game this is, you don't need to be a loud-mouth, drunk-off-your-♥♥♥ kind of guy/girl, or whatever. You can either be a hero or a villain; silent, at that.Anyway, the 'Game within a Game' comes from nowing how to survive out there. Yes, I know it's a game, and you can just reoad your last save if you screw up, but I'm one of te few who NEVER do that, because, as with real life, you can't just turn back time and forget about a bullet lodged in your shoulder, or a sledgehammer right to your skull. I love challenging myself like this: it makes the experience all the more real and authentic. In a war-torn land, you must do absolutely everything you can just to make it past a group of bandits. There are also too many recent games that rob the player of this particular experience—the true survival apect of a game. You might look at Fallout 3 and instantly compare it to something totally outlandish like Call of Duty 'Zombies' being the definition of hardcore, or Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode in Borderlands 2 [which actually is VERY challenging and rewarding], but for a game that has rightly earned a 'Game of the Year' tag, you need to try Fallout 3. It's one of the most authentic games from the last generation. ^w^

content:
5, 2014
												It took a real steamer like Fallout 4 to make me look at this a second time. Is it still full of ideas that run contrary to the spirit of the franchise? Sure. Is it still awfully written? Decidedly. Even then, this is still more ambitious and more successful when it puts in the effort than Fallout 4 is at it's very best.The ability to make weapons out of junk was great. I do like the attempt to prune down on useless skills from the classic series. There is a real crushing sense of atmosphere, it drives home the point that this is a very mean place that does not like you one bit. Everything about Galaxy News Radio is great. The main issue I have with the writing is that there are plenty of things in there that feel faithful to the franchise or just taking it to it's foregone conclusion, but very few of those are tied into the main story. That aside they had a interesting area like DC and have nothing really all that visually memorable. Lots of green and grey and brown. The weapons and armor are also horribly imbalanced against themselves.Anchorage is a linear, dull slog. The Pitt is amazing and showcases what the Bethesda writing team is capable of when they put some effort into it. Broken Steel is garbage. Point Lookout is very challenging, but interesting for it's non-linearity. Zeta is just Anchorage 2.0, this time in SPACE!Oh, and Oasis never happened.

content:
0, 2015
												Do not be fooled by the amount of hours played here: I had never owned it on Steam previously, but I have honestly put 200+ hours into this in my lifetime. I played Fallout 3 when it came out on a whim, not being overly familiar with the rest of the Fallout franchise, and it was the best decision I ever made, to stick to it even though at first I was not so sure if I liked it or not. Then, as I advanced properly into the Capital Wasteland and the story unfolded itself, it became my second favourite video game of all time (alongside BioShock 1/2). Though the engine may be old in today's standards, it does not discount anything at all; the grimy Wasteland has become a sort of home to me, every single character I have encountered is likeable, even the baddies that go around killing ♥♥♥♥, even the beloved cannibal-incestuous families of Andale that make you human-meat pies if you promise to stay quiet about their ways. This game shows you a portrayal of a world where the 50s never left it though technology went on, and accurately shows the progression of human survival after we succeeded at killing the world via nuclear warfare. There are so many heartwrenching moments, and just as many hilarious ones--all companions are likable, and every quest the Lone Wanderer undertakes is meaningful. Even the side quests serve good purposes, and I never tire of exploring the Wasteland though I may have scoured it from corner to corner by now. Like I've said, the Fallout world has become a very familiar place to me now, somewhere that is so replayable and full of vitality, ironically in a radiation-riddled landscape. I prefer it to Fallout: New Vegas only out of the story content, feeling the latter to be superior only by a hair. This was the first step of Bethesda's revival of the franchise, after all, and will remain forever in my heart as the best of the two. Please play this if you haven't, so that you can get a feel for the Fallout universe before Fallout 4 comes out. HYPE(my icon is actually of my Lone Wanderer, Eden, funnily enough)

content:
14, 2014
												This game, unlike the ElderScrolls Series, is not always for the casual player, even on very easy some enemies and places can be a nighmare of difficulty  if you dont have the right gear, or enough stimpacks of course, but saying that, I very much prefer this game to skyrim, possibly even Oblivion or Morrowind in the ElderScrolls series, and im very much anticipating Fallout 4 in the next year or two, People's faces and voices are much better in the fallout games than in the ElderScroll games, and you cant forget about 3dog, very good music, humor, quests, interesting things for people who love Washington D.C. as well and want to explore the radioactive wreckage of the capital, and the surrounding wastelands of course, It was interesting seeing the RobCo HQ, more vaults, and the Capital Itself, Very well made DLC, from aliens, to virtual reality, to slavers in pittsburgh, I would recommend this as a starter for Fallout games, even though it is the 3rd one, it is not very connected to the others, as it is from Bethesda, who did not make the first 2 games, although, the first 2 games excel in story and gameplay as well, and I recommend them as well, in the end its your choice, but if you have 20 bucks to spare, spend them on something that can provide limitless hours of entertainment, hundreds of locations, a good few laughs, good music, a Legendary Father, a few tear jerking moments, Horrifying Moral choices, and of course GARY! So yes, you should play this game, and talk about it, sing the songs outloud if you want, just have fun. Note, do not play this game just because you think, look, skyrim with guns, its alot more than that, and Warfare is slightly weak in this game, this is more for those Nerdy, Lore loving people out there, not the ones that claim to be real gamers, the ones who spend hundreds of hours finding every little secret, seeing every site, doing every mission, loading and reloading games to fix mistakes and prevent deaths, those people, those people are the real gamers, and the people who will enjoy this game the most.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2015
												To start off...Fallout is the game that you'll spend a lot of time playing while doing nothing but walk, talk, shoot and bash them with something or even punch it out with your own hands. For player who are similar to open world RPG (Skyrim, GTA) this is the game for you.The story set in the world after the nuclear war in the future and the protagonist was born and living safely underground after the war has ended. The father set out on a journey to recover the land and it is our job to find and help make it a better (or worse) place.The perk of playing this game is like any other open world series is that you can do anything and by 'anything' I mean everything. You can be the Good, the Bad or you can balance it out in your journey into the wasteland. There will be choices along the way which will make you say "Seriously? Do I really have to pick?" and then save at that point before making a decision and watch where your choices lead you.The outcome of the game is pretty much influent by how you play the game from the start to finish. There will be a lot of side quests which you can totally ignore them and still getting to the ending. (but they are worth it!)The combat system are not too chabby but not that great either. Since the game consists on the story more than the gameplay. Also, the difficulty of this game depends your your skills choice and how you manage it when when you level up. There will be many status like poison and radiation (it was a nuclear post-apocalyptic and all) .The AI or the enemies on this game are pretty easy to read (since they are only coming straight at you), but most of them are the hardhitters (mostly the non-human enemies) and they could totally whoop your butt into your last save in just a couple of hits (remember to save often!).The most important thing in this game is the soundtrack. It somehow became the best thing you can hear in the game while slaughter some radiated monsters. Also, the graphic might not be that great compare to these days' standard but there is nothing you can't fix with a little modding which can be found in many other reviews or community discussions.There are some downside of this game that many people are talking about like, can't play with windows 7 or higher but there are solutions. All you need to do is open up a browser (or two if you want) and type for "fallout 3 fix" or something similar to "Fallout 3 window 7/8 fix" and your problem will be gone in just a few mins. Other than OS problem the game doesn't have a cloud save which will be a problem because you will play this game for a long long time and you don't want to start over if your PC/Laptop just broken or you're changing them to a better one. But on the bright side, the game have save files for everytime you save during the game in your documents folder. I recommend you to make a backup once in a while or you will be just like me who have start all over again for 3 times already and it's pretty frustrating.All in all, Just buy it when it's on sales and play and I promise you won't regret it.

content:

												***IMPORTANT: if you want to play this game on Windows 7 and newer versions of windows, you'll likely need to download the Unooffical fallout 3 patch. Otherwise you'll find out very quickly that the game crashes all the time, making it unplayable. Just go to Nexus mod website (just use google) to download this mod, it's pretty much mandatory. Don't spend hours on the internet looking for ways to fix the issue, this mod will fix it all and it's very simple. And while you're there, get some of the other top mods that will greatly enhance your playing experience.***It's an absolutely brilliant game, when playing this game you HAVE to do all the major sidequests to experience and appreciate it fully. Don't rusth through it, take your time. The graphics may look a little old nowadays, but you can enhance them greatly with mods aswell. The main story is very good, the lore of the game is fantastic and the gameplay is also excellent (although, again mods will enhance this).I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games with an open world sandbox environment, but most importantly: I recommend this game for people who enjoy a great and emersive story. It's different than the Elder Scrolls but in many ways just as epic and emersive. If you like post-Apocalyptic settings like 'The Walking Dead' I'm sure you'll love scrounging through the metro stations and sewers of the DC area, encountering countless feral ghouls (zombies), Super Mutants and other mutated freaks! Extremely high replayability value aswell.

												Considering the age of this game, there is nothing new, innovative or otherwise interesting that I can say about this game that hasn't been said a million times before, so I'll keep it brief. This game is great. You should play it. Your friends should play it. Everyone you know should play it. Your dog should grow opposable thumbs and learn to play videogames just to play this one game. It's that good. I mean sure, running around a desolate wasteland looking for stuff to do isn't everyone's cup of tea. If you don't pay attention it can be hard to know what you're meant to be doing. It consistently crashes on my computer. It's buggy. But despite all that I'm reccomending the game. Why? Because it's that good. The story's good. The voice acting is a solid 8/10, the environments are lovingly - if drearily - crafted, the combat is well designed and intense, the exploration is genuine, the emotions are deep and the controls are intuitive. If you're on the fence, just get Fallout 3. Or wait until Fallout 4 comes out, then it'll probably be cheaper

												Probably one of the best RPG/Sci-Fi/Open World games that you can get. Really great. If you have Windows 7 or later, then just get a patch on Nexus, that will fix it, the game (as far as I remember/know) has problems running on Quad Core Processor. And some more stuff. Just google "Dansgaming - How to mod Fallout 3" there you can get many great ideas, and a very easy tutorial to fix Fallout 3, the first video should be about the patch, if you only want that one.Besides that, I can say that the game has some great moments, you have no idea how satisfying it is to throw a grenade at a bunch of raiders in slow-mo VATS. Just great.The game comes with some great DLC/Expansions to the main game, that is really worth checking out. If you have earlier tried out games such as Fallout 1-2 and New Vegas, or maybe some other games in the same genre, like the other Bethesda games, like Skyrim, this is worth trying out, trust me on that. And also, if you have played it 1-2 times, then try modding it, it can dramatically change your experience and look at the game, the modding community of the Bethesda games a thriving, and there are no short of people that will happily help you get starting modding.All in all, probably the greatest game I have ever played.PS: The reason I haven't so many hours, is because I played a pirated version before (I know, hang me), and when I got it myself, I had problems with the optimization part of Fallout 3 for Windows 7, all fixed now ofc.If you are unsure, then get it on a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												I'd highly recommend this game, to anybody!! I have plenty of reasons too!! Main Story and Karma System - It's been 300 years since fire rained from the sky, and you are a resident of Vault 101, in the DC Area. Raised inside this vault, which, nobody ever enters, or leaves. You awaken one day to sirens going off in the vault, and the vault door is open... Your father is gone. Everyone is mad at you for your father's actions, and you are forced to fight your way out... Thus begins the Lone Wanderers journey to find his father. You could either shape the Wasteland, or destroy it... with the karma system, you're veiwed as either a Hero or a Villian, and it also affects which followers or missions you could obtain...Side Quests and Characters - There will by many Characters you will meet in your travels... Some more rememberable than others, but one thing's for sure... If they have a name, chances are they will be dynamic, and will have a personality their own. Considering this is a Bethesda game, much like Oblivion or Skyrim, Side quests are in abundance. And you will NEVER run out of things to do in the Capitol Wastelands!Combat - Combat in Fallout 3 is quite amazing, with an amazeing selection of Weapons to choose from. Includeing a massive arsenal of Light guns, Heavy guns, Energy Weapons, a huge selection of Melee weapons, and, even your bare hands!! Plus, Fallout has it's own, exclusive fighting system, called V.A.T.S. Using VATS you can specifically target a limb on your enemy, at the cost of Action Points. With an added bonus, of being able to cripple that body part... Careful though, your body parts can be crippled too!!Skills and Stats - Skills are very helpful in this game, and most of them are pretty cool too! Every level you get to choose a new perk for your character. These perks could include a Mysterious Stranger who appears to help you in VATS mode, or even, the Ability to learn where each undiscovered building and cave is! Modding Community - Again, this is a Bethesda game, the modding community is pretty active... While, maybe not as much as their more recent games, you could still find plenty of what you need... (However, this game was meant to be played on an XP System, if you have Windows Vista, or Windows 7, you're going to have to spend some time tinkering with .ini files... It's all worth the effort though!!)Overall, I recommend this game, and I would give an easy 9/10. Yes it has it's problems, but mostly, it deserves the praise it gets, and I would easily say it's one of my favorite games to date.

												Honestly, this was my first game in the RPG genera, as I had not played any other RPG type games, and this title was recommended to me by a friend. content:
ber 16, 2016
												Fallout 3 is a wonderful open world game that only realizes it's full potential when heavily modded.  To get to to run properly on Windows 7 x64 without crashing at startup or upon loading a new game I had to:1. Add the following line to the Havok section of the fallout.ini:iNumThreads=22. Install and run FOSE (http://fose.silverlock.org/download/fose_v1_2_beta2.7z) instead of the Fallout exe, and install the New Vegas Anti Crash plugins( it works for Fallout 3 as well as New Vegas, and the Dl link is http://www.nexusmods.com/newvegas/mods/53635/?)The GFWL Disabler (http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/1086/?) might also help, and enabling the 4GB flag on the game's executable should reduce crashes if using 2K HD retextures like NeilMB. ENBoost could help as well.For modding the game, a good base to start is: http://wiki.step-project.com/User:Kelmych/Fallout3Improved textures, more weapons, more enemies, better lighting, new houses and companions, more interiors, increased difficulty...It will take at least a day to download and set all of those mods up though.
